Palm Springs Art Museum.name: Palm Springs Art Museum
reviews: Much much better than I expected. A must see experience.

We really enjoyed this museum. The Women and Glass exhibit is very good. I definitely think this museum is worth visiting. There’s some Dale Chihully pieces. There’s a nice sculpture park outside. Lots of interesting things to see. Great gift shop too.
Didn’t expect much but was pleasantly surprised at how nice the art and displays were. Nice array of modern art in many forms. Very walkable and enjoyable for a modest price.
If you like modern art then this is the place to go

The art museum is close to the main street in Palm Springs and has parking. The collection is fun and interesting wit the focus on modern art and a small western collection. The media include sculpture, glass, and painting. Outdoors on the lower level is a small but excellent sculpture Garden.

This is an impressive art museum, with several different types of exhibits, and a good number of works shown on display. There were particularly some very impressive modern art specimens as well as a special feature of female glass artists. A number of different genres are there. It is easy to do the entire museum; there is a nice flow from floor to floor.

In such a wealthy community one would hope for a more focused curatorial direction. There is some mice work on view, likely more in storage but it did not leave a strong impression. The auditorium is a nice facility
This museum has an excellent collection in a manageable building. Not too enormous or overwhelming, but you still get to see an incredible variety of work. Loved it.
We always like to come here when we are in Palm Springs. The museum is just the right size to spend a few hours admiring the modern art. Our favorite is always the glass.
We were in Palm Springs for a short vist. we enjoyed the Museum. It was located very convient to down town coverd parking was very convient.

I attended many lectures at the museum over the course of the extraordinary modernism week. Every time the standard exceeded expectations. The pop in bistro was wonderful. Lovely location in the sculpture area and great food

Worth a visit, we returned to enjoy the free admission Thursday 4-8. Probably enjoyed the crowd as much as the art. Each piece has information about it and several locations had docents speaking and a lecture in the auditorium was announced so a visit at this time offered benefits beyond the free admission.

Worth a short visit if you have time
Not the greatest art museum in the world but work a visit if your looking for something to do. Ample parking. Certain days the admission is free.
We viewed a special glass exhibit. Arrived late Thursday for free entry. Saw all we needed to see and then went for dinner.
We were very pleased with the museum. It is well laid out and has a very interesting collection for a museum of it's size.

In December we visited the glass art pieces by women artists. It was a well curated show as there was an excellent variety of pieces that used glass in diverse ways. Outside of this special exhibition, we noticed American crafts that showcased again different materials such as pottery, leather, fabric. As we climbed the stairs, I was impressed with the museums collection of acquisitions over time such as a Lipschitz. And further up still, the contemporary pieces made art accessible to all ages. I wanted to bring my grandkids back because I knew the colours, designs and topics would spark intriguing discussions. This collection and curation are jewels in a museum small enough not tire the viewer. 8mpressive

It was very informative about local culture and there was an excellent Glass exhibit by Women artists. The outdoor sculpture garden was a plus.

Excellent collection of art from many places as well as local connections. Certainly worth a couple of hours. Docents are knowledgeable and helpful. Easy access to displays and lots of information given in the galleries. Easy walk from downtown and near hiking trails.

This museum is easy to tour and offers convenient free parking. Exhibits in included mid-century modern furniture and art, a sculptural garden, contemporary paintings and sculptures, and an excellent temporary show on glass works by women.

This is a significant art museum, showing many major works, and significant regional work as well. The spaces are large and generous, the traveling exhibitions are unfailingly interesting, and the span of art shown will keep you engaged as you make your way through the museum. Cost of admission is reasonable, and this trip can be combined with other things to do in the immediate area.

After visiting Palm Springs for many years, I finally made it to the Art Museum and was blown away! It's immense and took us two visits to see it all. Loved everything we saw and how things were presented. We'll be back every visit!

I had gotten to the end of my visit to Palm Springs and had still not seen the Palm Springs Art Museum, so I squeezed in a 45-minute visit on a Monday afternoon. There were less than a dozen other visitors in the whole place (so that's a great time to go!). I was able to quickly cover three floors. The sculptures, paintings, and glasswork inspired awe and stirred the kid in me. Some of the permanent exhibits -- the giant spinning plates -- were downright fun! I highly recommend a visit here -- do it first, not last -- and I will go again when I can linger. The intricate detail and creativity of the current exhibit "No Glass Ceiling! Women Working in Glass Part 1" (through March 5, 2018) is worth a visit on its own. And if you love glasswork, there is a large Chihuly piece in the center of the museum. Note that adult admission to this museum is $12; it is free only at the Palm Desert location.

wWith the docent tou, r what a great introduction to their modern art collection! One of the best things we did in Palm Springs
Went Thursday late afternoon when admission is free. I’m guessing it was more crowded because of that but the art work was worth seeing! Top floor is the most interesting part.
A truly wonderful museum and an amazing experience. Well done Palm Springs! Thoroughly enjoyed everything we saw and would definitely go back and recommend it.

It was pretty warm the day I visited the area. Had been walking the main strip and was looking for a non-food/beverage spot to cool down.

It was easy to spend an hour casually looking around. Interesting Native American woven bowl collection located here. Also some older stone art from 900-600 B.C.E and 600-900 C.E.

Not a ton of stuff but well worth an hour or so of perusing.

A fantastic building with four floors of galleries and a sculpture garden! The art works on display ranged from ancient to current artists. Quite an interesting combination of artworks. We particularly enjoyed the Women in Glass show. Outstanding and fascinating works. Don’t miss this fabulous art museum!

This museum looks hugefrom the outside but has a nicely displayed collection and did not take but an hour and a half to see. There is a good variety and some western art and modern art.

If you have some spare time stop by the Palm Springs Art Museum, you won't be disappointed. The "No Glass Ceiling! Women Working in Glass, Part 1" alone was worth the price of admission. George Montgomery's hand crafted furniture was amazing! Great visit.

I specifically went to see Dale Chihuly, but they only have about half dozen pieces. However, there was a glass exhibit which was very interesting; modern local artists and native basket weaving. The gift shop was interesting. I would visit again if there was a special exhibit on.

Probably the largest piece of Chiluli glass ever, and the always surprising driftwood horse. Unique woven middle eastern "flowing" rug hanging that seems to say "we were once an ordered, disciplined and artful society and now have been reduced to chaos".

Very good basket collection, nice gift shop. Free parking. Coffee shop was closed midweek.

If nothing else, the building itself is worth the price of admission. Some very famous people and some very generous people have done the city Palm Springs a huge tribute.

With its various floors and the outdoor courtyard it does a great job of telling the story of the Desert West. I would say it was much more meaningful for me after taking a couple of the walking tours put on by the palm springs historical society. They are a must.

But there is much to enrich your life in the art museum.

My parents and I were visiting the Palm Springs area so we decided to check out the Art Museum. What an amazing surprise! Terrific collection and just the right size. We were there for the Kinesthesia exhibit which was excellent. Highly recommend!

First visit to PS: go here and cool down a bit. The first and second times to the museum, this is a short delight. Not too large for children - but hands off. This is a small museum with a rather diverse set of displays. The third visit was a little familiar. Make sure to get to the fun basement.

The permanent collection - featuring some examples of Native American, Western and modern art - is not very impressive. Free Thursday evenings after 4PM, but expect a crowd during the high tourist season. The Annenberg Theater in the museum is a very good venue for films.

Nice new building with plenty of space just not much in it. Saw women in glass, 20 pieces 4 good others to modern/abstract for me. Good collection of native baskets. Only one Moran and one Russell. My husband and I have been to this charming small museum twice in the past year.

always fun and with innovative and current themes.

The Palm Springs Art Museum is a treasure. There is a very eclectic permanent collection and some very nice visiting exhibits at the museum. In January there will be an Andy Warhol show that looks worth checking out.

I have a crew of high school and young adult kids with us on vacation. Finding a fun adventure everyone likes can be tricky. Yet, we did it with the museum. Fun exhibits that intrigued all ages and delighted all eyes. Just large enough to keep us entertained without overwhelmed. Incredible glass exhibit and extremely knowledgeable docents. Small Art Gem in Palm Springs

My wife and I love art and go to museums when we travel. Although we did not have high expectations in Palm Springs, we were surprised. The museum is not large, but has a good permanent collection and had two or three small special exhibits which were well curated. The modern statues and Latin early art were quite good. The contemporary art on the third floor is not my cup of tea, but is well exhibited and fun to see. Well worth the trip and right near downtown against the mountains.

Varied exhibits that offer something for everyone

I always try to visit this museum when I'm in Palm Springs. It's convenient and very affordable. They have interesting rotating exhibits and I usually find something in the permanent collection that I missed before. There is western art and beautiful desert landscapes from the California Impressionist school as well as contemporary art. The current exhibit of glass art by female artists ("No Glass Ceiling! Women Working in Glass, Part 1", through Mar. 5, 2018)) is awe inspiring on many levels. I also enjoyed the Kinetic art from Latin America ("Kinesthesia: Latin American Kinetic Art, 1954–1969", through Jan. 15, 2018). The Photo Secessionist work (through Mar. 28, 2018) is very noteworthy. There is a great little gift shop and a nice restaurant. The people who work there (many volunteers) are pleasant and very helpful.

Went with my wife and enjoyed the experience . They have an eclectic collection of paintings , sculptures and various artifacts appealing to many tastes . Some I found to be modern art wacky and others I found truly inspiring .

I was there when school children were touring the museum and it was a delight to see their faces light up when they saw something new and appealing . They have an outdoor sculpture gallery that is not to be missed . Mother Nature provides a backdrop that is nothing short of impressive .

Bottom line : very well done and worth the time to tour this wonderful museum .

This is a small museum with an interesting permanent collection and routinely mounts wonderful spcial exhibitions. Currently -- November 2017 -- two special exhibitions are well worth a visit. One major exhibition is of "kinetic" art by Latino artists. The selected items mounted in the exhibit feature light, shadow, and motion -- providing fascinating viewing. Special gallery installations invite the viewer to "take part" in the viewing with fun and interesting features after walking into the spaces. The museum also currently has a wonderful installation of glass art by very skilled women artists. Although the museum restaurant was closed for remodleing when this review was written, by the time many will read this, the restaurant will be reopened, providing a great place for a lunch or snack break.

"Whenever" is a good time to visit the Palm Springs Art Museum but now is an especially outstanding time. The current show, Kinesthesia, offers unique interactive experiences for visitors. At its entrance a large three-dimensional optical illusion that moves as you move contains a secret passage that, from a viewer's point of view, appears to lift one's soul from one's body! And then there's the much advertised color exhibit which, with a little experimentation of staring first at a wall, turns an immersive light experience into a psycheledelic room of rainbows! Many many fun and surprising experiences await you. And it's all part of Pacific Standard Time (thank you Getty) featuring Latin American artists. Don't miss it!

There was also an excellent collection of native baskets. While a small museum, there are some pieces by major artists such as Picasso, Chagall, and others. It's size makes it very accessible and you can easily see everything in just a couple of hours. The displays are very well done and well lighted. Definitely recommend a visit.

Modern and Architectural Art in an Open Design

The Palm Spring Art Museum has been around for decades, highlighting the arts of the Palm Springs Glitterati as well as the local early settlers. The museum is quite eclectic, with numerous rooms devoted to specific styles or pieces. The furniture section shows mid-century modern furniture, some of it a highlight of George Montgomery (an early movie cowboy turned cabinet maker) creations. The art of basketry was also shown in another room, while pottery was shown in another. A "pop-up" artist exhibit featured mache works, while an exterior sculpture garden showcases art out of the discarded. Modern paintings and sculpture round of the collection, with a few odd carpets and Inca carvings thrown in for good measure near a Chihuly glass sculpture. Overall, it was an interesting respite from the 125 F temperatures. Free on Thursdays after noon!

We were very pleasantly surprised by the wonderful exhibits at the Palm Springs Art Museum. We happened to be there in time to catch the "Women of Abstract Expressionism" exhibit, which was comprehensive and well-curated. Besides that exhibit, we especially enjoyed the contemporary art glass exhibit, which included pieces from several artists that we admire (e.g., Chihuly, Tagliapietra). This museum's collections/exhibits expose visitors to artistic diversity, for example, Movie star George Montgomery's furniture making, Picasso's clay statues, Native American basketry, art of the American West and more. The interior of the building is lovely - light and airy, and a cool respite from the extremely hot temperatures outside.The time we spent here was quite worthwhile. In fact, we didn't have time to see everything we wanted.

Note: If you happen to be there on a Thursday, the admission might be free (opens at noon that day - at least as of this writing). I think this encourages folks to be part of the Palm Springs Thursday night VillageFest event.
